learned about being a better Mentor um the first of of is it should
be challenging if you're mentoring somebody you really need to challenge them it's too easy um to agree to Mentor
somebody and just kind of say yep that's great job um or just do the thing that they're doing anyway are you really um
to to be effective you should push people out of their comfort zone because you know when people get out of their comfort zone is where they grow the most
so it's if if you are mentoring somebody don't go for the easy wins you want to
push people um make them a little bit uncomfortable you also find need to give them enough rope um too often I've seen
um team leads or or MERS go look oh look I'll just do this bit it's hard um you
can just do the easy bit so you do need to give people um enough rope you need
to let people make some mistakes and and learn some things for themselves um even if sometimes your spidey sense says H I
think that's going to go wrong for you um time boxing is really good to say hey look here's this thing I suspect you're
going to run into some issues let's give it half a day um so yeah you can really you you don't want to spoon feed
people you need to let them learn that stuff but you can help them by time boxing a little bit other thing I found
is really helpful is uh look longer range than today so you know I've said
what skills would you want to have in your next job which is not to say I want you to leave um but what is it that you
want to do next and let's find opportunities for that in there um now you know and that that helps sort of
with retention as well like if it is somebody that that is reporting to you and you're just teaching them the stuff that you absolutely need them to do
today that's why people leave jobs because they're bored and they're not engaged they're not challenged whereas if as part of mentoring you can say what
skills would you actually want to have in two or three years time and work on that now and find those opportunities
then um you know you get some really good benefits I found pairing works really
really well particularly on on new patterns new techniques things that are hard um you know not just you know

at the pro process um is is a really effective thing and showing a bit of vulnerability um we've got somebody else

of us has all the answers we just get faster at finding them
out um and some so another really part of good mentoring really important part of good mentoring is um setting
expectations um in a mentor relationship especially around goals and around time frames um so around goals it's important
to really establish firm goals from the beginning so something that I've seen a lot of is uh if someone someone will go
up to someone they admire and go can can you be my mentor um and because the person usually
is uh hoping to give back they'll say yeah sure let's do it um but
but what they really should be asking is well what do you want to get out of this or what do you want to achieve what what
does the mentee want to get out of it um and also does it align with what you yourself as a mentor can provide or what
what the mentor can provide um there's this thing about this kind of yeah nervous offer for help without much

the time not really being that useful and it tends to leave both people feeling guilty that it kind of failed
because neither of them got really what uh they wanted out of it um and the second thing is around

mentors who were kind of assigned to me and we went through that whole thing we didn't really have any um firm goals and
um then we had to I had to work out how to end it and um so it's also something
really really important to establish at the start um deciding when the mentoring should end I think a lot of people do forget about doing that and um that
helps avoid the awkward conversations as well um if it's not working for somebody um so chatting about that up front is

is um I don't know if people have experienced this but you learn a lot from teaching you might have you know I
know how to do this thing I can do it with my eyes closed but somebody asks you to explain it all of a sudden you've got to really really think about it and

what did I just do you know by being forced to actually look at that um you

internalized um a couple of other things is I found that younger people or people
early in their earlier in their career um have an enthusiasm and energy that we tend to lose as we get a little bit old
and ch so you know I remember you know earlier in my career something had come out and
I would you know jump on it and grab it and build something with it you know throw it away and go no that was terrible and start again and build it

always ask first can I give you some feedback do it early and do it often don't leave feedback for something
